message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The subdural hematoma and the presence of a cigarette burn suggest physical abuse. Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are a common finding in cases of physical abuse in young children. Posterior rib fractures may also be seen in physical abuse, but the retinal hemorrhages are a more specific finding. Burns to the buttocks are less specific for physical abuse and may suggest other types of trauma. Epidural hematoma is less likely in this case, as the CT scan revealed a subdural hematoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation with subdural hematoma and a cigarette burn on the forearm suggests child abuse. Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are the most common ocular findings in cases of child abuse. Posterior rib fractures may be present in cases of child abuse, but they are less specific findings. Burns to the buttocks are also possible in cases of child abuse, but the cigarette burn on the forearm is a more specific finding. Epidural hematomas are less common in cases of child abuse compared to subdural hematomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a subdural hematoma, lethargy, confusion, and a cigarette burn on the child's forearm are suggestive of child abuse. Among the options, bilateral retinal hemorrhages are commonly associated with abusive head trauma. Posterior rib fractures and burns to the buttocks may also be indicators of abuse, but bilateral retinal hemorrhages are more specific. Epidural hematoma is unlikely in this case as the CT scan revealed a subdural hematoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of lethargy and confusion after a traumatic event, along with the presence of a subdural hematoma and a cigarette burn on the patient’s arm, suggests non-accidental trauma (NAT). Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are a common finding in NAT and it is the most likely additional finding. Posterior rib fractures and burns to buttocks are also common findings in NAT, but they are not as strongly associated with this type of trauma as retinal hemorrhages. Epidural hematoma is less likely because the mechanism of injury is not consistent with an epidural hematoma.

The presentation is highly suggestive of non-accidental trauma, also known as child abuse, and the most likely additional finding is bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Posterior rib fractures and epidural hematoma are less likely in this case, and burns to the buttocks are not commonly associated with this type of trauma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lethargy and confusion, along with a subdural hematoma and cigarette burn, suggest non-accidental trauma, also known as child abuse. Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are a common finding in cases of shaken baby syndrome, which is a form of non-accidental trauma. The other options are not typically associated with this type of trauma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a subdural hematoma and a cigarette burn suggests physical abuse. Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are commonly associated with shaken baby syndrome, which can result in subdural hematoma. Posterior rib fractures are associated with child abuse as well, but they are less specific for shaken baby syndrome. Burns to buttocks are not commonly associated with physical abuse in this context, and epidural hematoma is less likely given the location of the subdural hematoma.

Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are often seen in cases of abuse or non-accidental trauma, while the other options are less commonly associated with this presentation.

Bilateral retinal hemorrhages are a classic finding in shaken baby syndrome, which is a severe form of physical abuse. None of the other options are typically associated with shaken baby syndrome.
